natural problem: How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$
natural solution: We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\

& \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n > 0"
and h1 : "finite {1..16}"
and h2 : "distinct [1..(16::nat)]"
shows  "card {x - y | x y. x \<in> {1..16} \<and> y \<in> {1..16} \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> x - y > 0} = 15"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\
 & \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n > 0"
and h1 : "finite {1..16}"
and h2 : "distinct [1..(16::nat)]"
shows  "card {x - y | x y. x \<in> {1..16} \<and> y \<in> {1..16} \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> x - y > 0} = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a set of distinct positive integers from 1 to 16, how many distinct positive differences can be formed between any two distinct numbers? The final answer is 15.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..16}"
and h1 : "finite S"
and h2 : "distinct S"
shows  "card {x - y | x y. x \<in> S \<and> y \<in> S \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> x > y} = 15"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\
 & \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..16}"
and h1 : "finite S"
and h2 : "distinct S"
shows  "card {x - y | x y. x \<in> S \<and> y \<in> S \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> x > y} = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Consider a set S containing the integers from 1 to 16 inclusive. Find the number of distinct differences x - y, where x and y are elements of S, and x is greater than y. The final answer is 15.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>z. z > 0 \<and> z = abs (x - y))"
shows  "card {z. z > 0 \<and> (\<exists>x y. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> z = abs (x - y))} = 15"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\
 & \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>z. z > 0 \<and> z = abs (x - y))"
shows  "card {z. z > 0 \<and> (\<exists>x y. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> z = abs (x - y))} = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider the set A containing integers from 1 to 16. How many distinct positive differences can be formed from pairs of distinct elements in the set? The final answer is 15.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..16}"
and h1 : "finite A"
shows  "card {d. \<exists> a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> d = a - b} = 15"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\
 & \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..16}"
and h1 : "finite A"
shows  "card {d. \<exists> a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> d = a - b} = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the number of distinct differences that can be formed by subtracting any two distinct elements from the set of integers $\{1, 2, 3, \dots, 16\}$. The final answer is 15.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes diff_count :: nat
assumes h0 : "diff_count = card {(a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..16} \<and> b \<in> {1..16} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a - b > 0}"
shows  "diff_count = 15"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\
 & \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes diff_count :: nat
assumes h0 : "diff_count = card {(a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..16} \<and> b \<in> {1..16} \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a - b > 0}"
shows  "diff_count = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: How many distinct positive differences can be formed by subtracting any two distinct numbers from the set {1, 2, 3, ..., 16}? The final answer is 15.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..16}"
and h1 : "card {d. \<exists> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> d = abs (a - b)} = n"
shows  "n = 15"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\
 & \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..16}"
and h1 : "card {d. \<exists> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> d = abs (a - b)} = n"
shows  "n = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider the set $S = \{1, 2, 3, \dots, 16\}$. Find the number of distinct positive differences that can be obtained by subtracting any two distinct elements from the set $S$. The final answer is $15$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: "int set" and D :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 16}"
and h1 : "D = {abs (x - y) | x y. x \<in> S \<and> y \<in> S \<and> x \<noteq> y}"
shows  "card D = 15"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\
 & \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes S :: "int set" and D :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 16}"
and h1 : "D = {abs (x - y) | x y. x \<in> S \<and> y \<in> S \<and> x \<noteq> y}"
shows  "card D = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a set $S$ containing all integers between 1 and 16 inclusive. Define another set $D$ as the set of absolute differences between any two distinct elements of $S$. Find the number of elements in set $D$. The final answer is 15.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "int set" and count_diff :: "int \<Rightarrow> int set \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. count_diff n A = card {abs (x - y) | x y. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> abs (x - y) = n}"
shows  "card {count_diff n A | n. n > 0 \<and> n \<in> A} = 15"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\
 & \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "int set" and count_diff :: "int \<Rightarrow> int set \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. count_diff n A = card {abs (x - y) | x y. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> A \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> abs (x - y) = n}"
shows  "card {count_diff n A | n. n > 0 \<and> n \<in> A} = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider a set $A$ containing the integers from 1 to 16. Define a function "count_diff" that takes an integer $n$ and a set $A$ as its input and returns the number of distinct pairs of elements $(x, y) \in A$ such that their absolute difference is equal to $n$. How many different values of "count_diff" can be obtained for integers $n$ greater than 0 and belonging to the set $A$? The final answer is 15.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> n = \<bar>a - b\<bar>)"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 15 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> n = \<bar>a - b\<bar>)"
shows  "card {n. n > 0 \<and> (\<exists> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> n = \<bar>a - b\<bar>)} = 15"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 We can see that the maximum positive difference is $16 - 1 = 15.$ Some quick calculations show that we can get all values between $1$ and $15.$ \begin{align} 16 - 1 &= 15 \\ 16 - 2 &= 14 \\ 16 - 3 &= 13 \\
 & \ \,\vdots \\ 16-14&=2\\ 16-15&=1 \end{align} Therefore there are $\boxed{15}$ different positive integers that can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> n = \<bar>a - b\<bar>)"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 15 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> n = \<bar>a - b\<bar>)"
shows  "card {n. n > 0 \<and> (\<exists> a b. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> n = \<bar>a - b\<bar>)} = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a set S containing the numbers from 1 to 16, how many distinct positive differences can be found between any two different numbers in the set? The final answer is 15.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes S :: "int set" and diff_set :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..16}"
and h1 : "diff_set = {abs(x - y) | x y. x \<in> S \<and> y \<in> S \<and> x \<noteq> y}"
shows  "card diff_set = 15"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different positive integers can be represented as a difference of two distinct members of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14, 15, 16 \}?$ The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof

 *)

theorem
fixes S :: "int set" and diff_set :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {1..16}"
and h1 : "diff_set = {abs(x - y) | x y. x \<in> S \<and> y \<in> S \<and> x \<noteq> y}"
shows  "card diff_set = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a set S containing integers from 1 to 16. Define another set, diff_set, as the set of all absolute differences between distinct elements of S. Find the number of elements in diff_set. The final answer is 15.
